coredata.dc:title: Coverage-dependent behavior of ultrathin Cu films on Pt(111): UHV and electrochemical studies
coredata.dc:creator: Leung, Lam-Wing H.
Gregg, Thomas W.
Wayne Goodman, D.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Submonolayer to monolayer coverages of Cu electrodeposited and vacuum-deposited onto a well-characterized Pt (111) surface were studied in both ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) and electrochemical environments using a combined UHV-electrochemical apparatus. Substantial discrepancy was observed between the voltammetrically measured Faradaic charge and the theoretically expected value based on UHV determined Cu coverages. For Cu coverages >0/5 monolayers (ML), θ Cu>0.5, the Coulometrically determined Cu coverage was too low by up to 30%; for θ Cu<0.5, the Coulometrically determined Cu coverage was too high by up to 50%. A significant contribution to this discrepancy at θ Cu>0.5 is believed to be the partially charged nature of the Cu adlayers. For θ Cu<0.5 this discrepany can be accounted for by the partial discharge of coadsorbed anions during the electrooxidative desorption of Cu.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 188, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 January 1992 Coverage-dependent behavior of ultrathin Cu films UHV and electrochemical studies Lam-Wing H. Leung, Thomas W. Gregg and D. Wayne Goodman Department c>f Chemistry, Texas A & M University, College Station, 1")( 77843-3255, USA Received 8 October 199 l on Pt( 111 ): Submonolayer to monolayer coverages ofCu electrodeposited and vacuum-deposited onto a well-characterized Pt ( 11 I ) surface were studied in both ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) and electrochemical environments using a combined UHV-electrochemical ap- paratus. Substantial discrepancy was observed between the voltammetrically measured Faradaic charge and the theoretically expected value based on UHV determined Cu coverages. For Cu coverages > 0.5 monolayers (ML), Oc,u > 0.5, the Coulometri- cally determined Cu coverage was too low by up to 30%; for Ocu < 0.5, the Coulometrically determined Cu coverage was too high by up to 50%. A significant contribution to this discrepancy at O~,u > 0.5 is believed to be the partially charged nature of the Cu adlayers. For 0cu < 0.5 this discrepancy can be accounted for by the partial discharge of coadsorbed anions during the electrooxi- dative desorption of Cu. It is now well known that the modification of metal surfaces by deliberate addition of another metal component can result in selective improvement or degradation in catalytic activity, selectivity and re- sistance to poisoning of such surfaces in both gas- phase and liquid-phase environments [1-6]. We have recently demonstrated that ultrathin Cu films on Pt ( 11 1 ) prepared either by electrodeposition from a Cu2~-containing solution or by vapor-deposition in ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) environment displayed essentially identical electrochemical stripping pro- files in 0.2 M HCIO4 [ 7]. More significantly, we have observed that the Faradaic charge measured for the monolayer Cu stripping peak in both cases is sub- stantially lower than the theoretically expected value for a Cu monolayer in registry with the Pt( 1 1 1 ) sub- strate surface [ 7 ]. This observation, along with UHV surface science studies of Cu overlayers on Pt( 1 1 1 ) which have shown that a complete Cu monolayer is formed prior to the formation of Cu multilayers [ 8- 10 ], led to the conclusion that the Cu monolayers in the electrochemical environment near their stripping potentials are partially charged as a consequence of transfer of electronic charge from the metal adlayer to the Pt( 1 1 1 ) substrate [7]. We now report an ex- tension of this combined UHV surface science and electrochemical study which shows that substantial discrepancy is observed between the Faradaic charge measured for the Cu desorption feature and the the- oretically expected value for submonolayer to mono- layer coverages of Cu on Pt ( 1 1 1 ). Furthermore the degree and sign of the discrepancy is strongly cov- erage dependent. In addition, Auger electron spec- troscopic (AES) analysis of the emersed Cu/Pt( 1 1 1 ) electrodes indicates the presence of substantial amounts of chlorine and oxygen (from perchlorate ions) which vary linearly as a function of Cu cov- erage. These results therefore strongly indicate that the Cu adlayer is partially charged at submonolayer to monolayer coverages in the electrochemical en- vironment. In addition, results obtained from the present combined voltammetric and AES study strongly imply that discharging of adsorbed anions occurs during the electrooxidative desorption of Cu. Fig, 1 shows plots of the ratio of measured to the- oretical Faradaic charge, Q .... /Q,h .... as a function of Cu coverage in monolayers (ML), Oc,u, on To whom correspondence should be addressed. 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 © 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. Plots of the ratio of voltammetrically measured to theo- retically expected Faradaic charge, Qn~¢~/Qth~o~, in 0.2 M HCIO4 as a function of copper coverage, 0Cu, for vacuum-deposited Cu on Pt( 111 ) (see text and footnote 1 ). ;5 0.45 - 0.40 0.35 ~J IJ [J 0,30 r] l; 0.20 ~ n o,5 i 0.10k ~ r [] o.osy~ ~- 0 O0 ~ + 1 • .... t L ] 0.0 0.2 0.4 0.6 08 1.0 0Cu (ML) Fig. 2. Plots of chlorine coverage, 0~, as a function of copper cov- erage, 0Cu, for emersed Cu/Pt( 111 ) electrodes (see text, fool- notes 2 and 3 ). Pt( 111 ) ~. The Cu/Pt ( 111 ) surfaces were prepared in UHV ~2 and the Oc.u values determined precisely by AES [7-10]. The deviation of the Q .... /Qtheor ratio from unity displayed in fig. 1 is of central im- portance since a ratio of unity is expected if the Cu adlayer on Pt(lll) in 0.2 M HCIO4 is fully dis- charged. Close inspection of fig. 1 reveals that the resulting plots can in general be separated into three regions: ( 1 ) for 0cu < 0.4, the ratio lies above unity; (2) at 0.4~< 0cu~<0.6, the ratio is close to unity; and (3) at 0co>0.6, a ratio below unity is obtained. As mentioned previously, a ratio below unity ob- tained for Oc~ = 1.0 can be explained by the partially charged nature of the Cu monolayer in the electro- chemical environment [7]. The charged nature of the first monolayer of Cu is demonstrated in fig. 2 ~L The Q .... /Qtheor values were obtained by rationing the Fara- daic charge measured from the stripping peak at ~0.5 V in 0.2 M HC104 [7] to the theoretically expected value which was deduced from the 0cu value determined from AES. For a Cu monolayer in registry with the Pt( 111 ) substrate surface, the theoretically expected value is 480 laC cm-2. ~2 Cu was dosed in UHV at a substrate temperature ~ 300-400 K by evaporation from a Cu wire wrapped around a tantalum filament [7]. It is important to note that following vacuum deposition of a given coverage of Cu, the Pt( 111 ) electrode was introduced into the electrochemical cell under a con- trolled potential of -0.2 V to avoid any loss of Cu to the elec- trolyte. The experiments reported here were conducted in an apparatus consisting of an electrochemical chamber (EC) at- tached directly to a UHV chamber. This combined UHV-EC apparatus is more fully described in ref. [ 11 ]. which displays plots of CI coverage ~3 0(71' as a func- tion of Oco as determined by AES for an emersed Pt( 1 1 1 ) electrode ~4. The monotonic increase in 0~,~ with increasing Oc.u can be attributed to the partially charged nature of the Cu adlayer at the emersion potential. While the presence of a partially charged Cu ad- layer can fully explain the observed deviation of the O .... /Qtheor ratio from unity at 0cu>0.6 (fig. 1), questions do arise regarding the possibility of ad- ditional interactions between the electrolyte and the Cu/Pt(lll) surface at Oc:u<~0.6 where Q .... / Qtheor>~ 1.0. Although a marked change in the dou- ble-layer structure during the electrooxidative de- ~3 ~4 Oct values were determined from the AES [ CI ( 181 eV ) / Pt (237 eV ) ] ratio and a saturation coverage of ~ 0.45 ML [ 12 ]. The presence of oxygen in amounts consistent with stoichiometric C104 was indicated by an Auger feature at 510 eV. The poten- tial sweep curves in these studies were characteristic of those published curves for a chloride-free electrolyte (see, for ex- ample, ref. [ 13 ] ). The data points shown in fig. 2 were obtained from a number of experiments which employed the following conditions: (a) electrodeposition of various coverages of Cu in a solution con- taining 0.05 M HCIO4+ 0.025 M Cu2+, rinsed with water and transferred to the UHV chamber: (b) same as in (a) but with- out rinsing; (c) vacuum-deposition of various coverages of Cu and transferred to the electrochemical cell (0.05 M HC104) under controlled potential, the electrode potential was scanned to +0.3 V and rinsed with water and transferred back to the UHV chamber. No loss of Cu was noted in these experiments by AES. 468 Volume 188, number 5,6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 17 January 1992 sorption of Cu could possibly lead to the aforemen- tioned deviation, it is unrealistic that such modification could be the major contributor to the observed deviation ~s. We therefore believe that for 0cu ~< 0.6, significant partial discharge of coadsorbed anions occurs during the electrooxidative desorption process, thus accounting for the excess Faradaic charge. The dispersed and partially charged nature of the Cu adlayer at Oc° <~ 0.6, in principle, could al- low the coadsorbed anions to be interdispersed with the Cu adatoms, in correlated positions [14]. Re- cent emersion experiments in our labs [ 15 ] using low energy electron diffraction (LEED) have identified three ordered structures for this system: (2 X.,/3) at 0c~=0.7-1.0; (2 X2xf3) at 0cu=0.3-0.7; and ( 1 × 1 ) at 0Cu = 0.8-1.0. These arrangements, in turn, would facilitate the discharging process during the elec- trooxidative desorption of Cu. Clearly, the more di- lute the Cu within these structures, the larger the partial charge will be on the Cu. Thus the contri- bution of the anions to the measured charge during the oxidative stripping more than compensates for the increase in the oxidation state of the Cu at 0cu<0.6. At 0cu>0.6, where the Cu adlayer is be- lieved to be in the form of large 2D islands [8-10], anion coadsorption and their accompanying dis- charge during the Cu electrooxidation would be min- imal. The maintenance of the large 2D Cu mor- phology during the electrooxidative desorption process for 0cu> 0.6 is consistent with the observed desorption kinetics ~6 Recent work by Magnussen and co-workers [ 14 ] using in situ scanning tunneling microscopy (STM) indicates that Cu coverages on Au(1 11 ) deduced from the STM images differ markedly from the cov- erages evaluated Coulometrically. For example, an STM image which can accommodate only 0.33 ML Cu yielded a charge corresponding to >/0.5 ML Cu. This ratio of the Coulometrically measured Cu cov- erage to the actual Cu coverage is very close to that found for Cu/Pt( 11 1 ) in fig. 1. Similarly, Chert et al. [ 16 ] using atomic force mi- croscopy (AFM), have identified discreet structures for UPD Ag on Au( 111 ) which are interpreted as metal-anion complexes. Furthermore little agree- ment was found in this study between the AFM-de- termined Ag coverages and those predicted from Coulometric measurements. More recently Tadjeddine et al. [17] have used SEXAFS to characterize three distinct structures of Cu on Au( 1 11 ), a x/3X x/3 structure at 0cu=0.3, a c(5×5) structure at 0cu=0.6, and a ( 1X 1 ) struc- ture at Ocu= 1.0. This work also showed, using XANES, that the oxidation state of the high cover- age Cu to be + 1, very close to the value estimated by us for high coverage Cu on Pt. In view of these latter results and our recent LEED results [ 15 ], the changes observed in the normalized charge for the stripping of Cu from Pt are believed to be associated with discreet structures related to specific Cu coverages. Although more work is required to unambiguously verify the above assertions, we believe that the pres- ent approach and results provide interesting and ex- citing new information regarding the behavior of metal overlayers in an electrochemical environment. Further work involving other admetals as well as other supporting electrolytes is in progress. "5 Although it is difficult to evaluate the non-Faradaic charge during the electrooxidative process, a rough estimate can be made as follows. If we assume a capacitance of roughly 30-40 ~tF cm-2 for the Cu/Pt( 111 ) surface, to compensate for the difference between the measured and theoretically expected charge (40-100 laC cm-2), a change of 1-2 V in the potential of zero charge during the Cu stripping process would be re- quired. Such a change is highly unlikely in the present system. ,6 The stripping curves for various coverages of Cu from 0cu=0.05-1.0 do not constitute a "family" of curves. That is, the curve for 0.5 ML Cu, for example, does not fall within the 1.0 ML curve, but is shifted significantly cathodic. The impli- cation of this is that the kinetics of the structural transforma- tion from one Cu coverage to a second is very slow relative to the rate of the potential sweep. [ 17] A. Tadjeddine, D. Guay, M. Ladonceur and G. Tourillon, Phys. Rev. Letters 66 (1991) 2235. 470 of the Coulometrically measured Cu cov- erage to the actual Cu coverage is very close to that found for Cu/Pt( 11 1 ) in fig. 1. Similarly, Chert et al. [ 16 ] using atomic force mi- croscopy (AFM), have identified discreet structures for UPD Ag on Au( 111 ) which are interpreted as metal-anion complexes. Furthermore little agree- ment was found in this study between the AFM-de- termined Ag coverages and those predicted from Coulometric measurements. More recently Tadjeddine et al. [17] have used SEXAFS to characterize three distinct structures of Cu on Au( 1 11 ), a x/3X x/3 structure at 0cu=0.3, a c(5×5) structure at 0cu=0.6, and a ( 1X 1 ) struc- ture at Ocu= 1.0. This work also showed, using XANES, that the oxidation state of the high cover- age Cu to be + 1, very close to the value estimated by us for high coverage Cu on Pt. In view of these latter results and our recent LEED results [ 15 ], the changes observed in the normalized charge for the stripping of Cu from Pt are believed to be associated with discreet structures related to specific Cu coverages. Although more work is required to unambiguously verify the above assertions, we believe that the pres- ent approach and results provide interesting and ex- citing new information regarding the behavior of metal overlayers in an electrochemical environment. Further work involving other admetals as well as other supporting electrolytes is in progress. "5

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Submonolayer to monolayer coverages of Cu electrodeposited and vacuum-deposited onto a well-characterized Pt (111) surface were studied in both ultrahigh vacuum (UHV) and electrochemical environments using a combined UHV-electrochemical apparatus. Substantial discrepancy was observed between the voltammetrically measured Faradaic charge and the theoretically expected value based on UHV determined Cu coverages. For Cu coverages >0/5 monolayers (ML), θ Cu>0.5, the Coulometrically determined Cu coverage was too low by up to 30%; for θ Cu<0.5, the Coulometrically determined Cu coverage was too high by up to 50%. A significant contribution to this discrepancy at θ Cu>0.5 is believed to be the partially charged nature of the Cu adlayers. For θ Cu<0.5 this discrepany can be accounted for by the partial discharge of coadsorbed anions during the electrooxidative desorption of Cu.
